awd_titl_txt: Gravitation theory and black hole thermodynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
The research supported by this award aims to further our understanding of  gravitational physics in areas ranging from fundamental theory to astrophysical phenomena. Despite the fact that General Relativity, Einstein's theory of gravity, is well-confirmed by many tests and observations, outstanding  puzzles in both cosmology and quantum gravity motivate investigation of the properties and predictions of various modifications. This research will study, in particular, theories with a preferred reference frame. The focus will be on stability and dynamical viability of such theories.  A second theme of the research concerns properties and phenomena associated with spinning black holes, which are the universal endpoint of complete gravitational collapse.  Topics to be studied include the mathematical description of such black holes, the limitations on their spin rate, and mechanisms that might produce the extremely energetic jets of matter that are observed to be ejected from their neighborhood.  A particular such mechanism involves magnetic energy concentrated in tube-like structures behaving as elastic strings. A third area of the research aims to develop a better understanding of the nature of the entropy of black holes and other influence horizons. In particular, while this entropy appears to obey the second law of thermodynamics, the exact meaning of that statement and its validity remain  murky. 

The results of this research on modifications of General Relativity  will produce a better understanding of the possibilities and problems that entails,  and new ways to test the theory and to interpret anomalies if such should arise. The work on spinning black holes will provide insight into the dynamical behavior of such objects, and may contribute to understanding the origin of the high energy jets they sometimes generate. The work on black hole entropy attempts to capitalize on the  tantalizing hints of black hole thermodynamics, to use those hints  to discover principles of that may govern the underlying theory of  quantum gravity.   The results of this research will be disseminated through written articles, as well as seminars, conference talks, and lecture series. The research will help to train future scientists in both this research area and related fields through graduate and undergraduate courses taught at the University of Maryland, and through the supervision of research by  undergraduates, graduate students, and postdocs.  In addition the PI will give scientific talks to the public in various forums, to share the insights and excitement that science has provided about the universe and our place in it.

por.por_cntn:
The work on this grant involved several areas of classical and quantum gravity and astrophysics. In addition to a number of miscellaneous areas of research, the major areas of focus and progress were as follows: 1) Nine publications involved the properties and phenomenology of a class of gravity theories modifying general relativity,  designed to test for the possibility of preferred frame effects. Some highlights are the characterization of non-spinning black holes in these theories, cosmological models, and analysis of the dynamical stability of the theories; 2) Eight publications aimed at deepening our understanding of the nature of the entropy of black hole horizons and other sorts of horizons. In particular some of this work included analyzing curvature corrections to the standard area law for the entropy, and issues arising in the interpretation of horizon entropy as quantum entanglement entropy of vacuum fluctuations; 3) Eight publications were devoted to improving our understanding of the nature and validity of the generalized second law (GSL) of horizon thermodynamics. The highlight of this work is a pair of papers by graduate student Aron Wall which provided a new perspective on this law and provided the most general proofs available to date; 4) Mathematical tools were developed for the field of force-free plasma electrodynamics, which is relevant in particular for describing the high energy astrophysical environments of neutron stars and black holes.  The highlight is a long paper explaining and reviewing the field as applied in astropysics, and presenting the new tools. Using these tools, new solutions to the field equations were found.

The results of the work are recorded in publications posted at arXiv.org, then published in journals or books. Numerous seminars and conference talks were given, many of them recorded. Colloquia for physics, math or astronomy departments were given as well.

In the area of instruction, the PI led a string theory study group for graduate students in Spring 2010, and a quantum gravity study group for graduate students in Fall 2012 and Spring 2013. He also gave a minicourse of eight lectures on Spacetime Approach to Force-free magnetospheres at Perimeter Institute in Spring 2014 (the lectures were recorded and are available on the PIRSA website), and taught a graduate course in general relativity in Fall 2014. Extensive lecture notes are available online.
   
The grant promoted the intellectual and professional growth of postdoctoral scholars, graduate students, and undergraduate students, who were supported in part by the grant and mentored by the PI.
